title: History of Christianity in China
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at giving the students a macro historical picture of Christianity in China from the seventh century to the present. Special attention will be paid to the interaction between Christianity and the Chinese society.
outcome: Learning outcomes (1) To assist students to understand the historical development of Christianity in China (2) To assist students to acquaint the methods of conducting research on Chinese church history Attitude Outcomes (1) To develop and affirm students’ identity towards Chinese church history
syllabus: 1.Voices from the Past1: Writing the History of Christianity in China2.Experience: Empiricist Research on Christianity in Contemporary China3.Preface: Traces of Early Christian Encounters4.Friendship: Images of the Jesuits in Imperial China5.The Task: The “Protestant Plan” for China6.Sisters: Portraits of Women in Chinese Christianity7.Culture: The Story of 19th-century Chinese Protestantism8.Contextualization: In Search of an Indigenous Chinese Christianity9.Conflict: Remembering the Anti-Christian Movement10.Officials: Tracking Chinese Christianity vis-à-vis CCP rule11.Perceptions: Histories of Contemporary Chinese Christianities12.Student Presentations: proposals

title: History of Christianity in Asia
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course introduces the students to the history of Christianity in Asia, from the first century and the mission to India through the Sassanid and the Mongolian period, the spread of Roman-Catholic and Protestant faith in the colonial era to the development of independent Christianity since the 20th century. A significant focus of the course will be on more recent developments in different parts of Asia.
outcome: a) The students will gain an understanding of the historical development of Christianity in Asia and will learn to perceive and appreciate Christianity in Asia as a partly parallel and independent rather than as latter development to Christianity in Europe. b) The students will learn about the contemporary challenges of Christian churches in different contexts of Asia and the reasons for different growth developments. They will learn to distinguish between joint Asian concerns and the concerns of particular contexts. c) In the different historical developments of Christianity in Asia, the students will encounter different models of Christianity and Christian relations to their cultural environment. The students will equally discover different issues of contextualization. d) The students will develop sensitivity regarding mission, ecumenism, and contextualization in the postcolonial Asian context and learn about different Christian responses to the multi-religious context of Asia. The focus on the diversity of Christian churches and faith expressions in Asia leads beyond the dualism of local church and church in the West and helps perceive Christianity in a multi-polar world.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction to the course Week 2: The spread of Christianity in the first 10 centuries Week 3: Asian Christianity from 1000 to 1800 Week 4: The emergence of the Protestant mission movement Week 5: Protestant Christianity across 19th century Asia Week 6: Korean Christianity Week 7: Christianity and Buddhism in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia Week 8: Christianity in Thailand Week 9: Christianity in Myanmar Week 10: Christianity facing Islam  Week 11: Christianity in India and Nepal Week 12: Global faith movements in the Asian context Week 13: Conclusions

title: Systematic Theology I
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Systematic theology can be understood as the theological discipline that constructively articulates the meaning, coherence, and implications of Christian beliefs. This course aims at providing students with a solid methodological foundation for the study of systematic theology by investigating various issues that belong to the “prolegomena” of systematic theology, including the formative factors of theology (such as revelation, Bible, tradition, experience, reason, and culture), theological language, and theological methods.
outcome: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have an historical overview of the major paradigms in Christian theology; (b) to understand significant issues and diverse views regarding the formative factors of theology (especially the Bible, but also tradition, culture, theological language, etc.); (c) to have basic knowledge of exemplary theological systems and methods; (d) to be able to think analytically and critically in the field of theology.

title: Systematic Theology II
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to a solid understanding of major Christian doctrines, including the diversity of views, major historical developments, and significant issues involved, and their interrelations; (b) to be able to read and understand the writings of some important theologians, especially those in the patristic era, the Reformation era, and the twentieth century; (c) to be able to critically articulate the relevance of systematic theology for Christian life and churches.
outcome: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to a solid understanding of major Christian doctrines, including the diversity of views, major historical developments, and significant issues involved, and their interrelations; (b) to be able to read and understand the writings of some important theologians, especially those in the patristic era, the Reformation era, and the twentieth century; (c) to be able to critically articulate the relevance of systematic theology for Christian life and churches.

title: Local Church Study
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at helping students to gain a comprehensive understanding on the history of the field of study namely congregational study. It also helps student to critically understand the theologies behind different models of church, and how these theologies of church are translated into practice in the practical world. Special attention will be paid to the Hong Kong church--its historical developoment, its theologies, its denominational traditions, polity and others. Students will have chance to analyse their own churches according to what they learn from class.
outcome: 知識方面：  從歷史角度初步了解本地新教之發展與現況  把握本地新教堂會的社會學及神學實況  學習分析影響著本地新教堂會發展之幾個因素  認識堂會研究之方法及方法論基礎 態度方面：  對堂會發展與現況持批判而開放的態度  更關心本地堂會發展 技巧方面：  能初步以堂會研究之方法去分析本地教會議題
syllabus: 課程簡介 本地新教教會面貌 堂會研究的學科面貌 教會增長的論述  本地堂會之增長狀況  香港堂會組織特色與增長之關係  中小型堂會的狀況及反思  教會增長在西方的論述 本地新教教會之神學面貌與傳承 有關堂會牧者的論述  本地堂會牧者之一般狀況  本地堂會牧者之流動狀況  堂會牧者所遇見之困難與權力分析  本地堂會牧者/信徒領袖心目中的牧職定義  本地女牧者之體會  本地教會在本土的公眾形象  本地堂會牧者之神學傾向及不同的神學傾向淺解  教牧之政治參與模式與立場傾向 教會分析工具：自然的教會、一些常用量化工具 教會分析工具：生態分析 “本地堂會考察” 小組報告

title: Pastoral Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course covers three areas: 1) the historical and theological position of Pastoral Theology in Theological Studies and its uniqueness; 2) different types of Pastoral Theology and their aims; and 3) Ancient and contemporary church models and pastoral emphases.
outcome: To understand what is Pastoral Theology with reflection from personal pastoral experience. To construct Pastoral Theology from the Bible, church and Chinese cultural traditions.  To understand different emphases of Pastoral Theology from multiple perspectives and from histories of different denominations.
syllabus: Session 1: The Pastor as a Person (1)—Pastor’s Relationships: The Congregation, Collegiality, Denomination and the Society.Session 2: The Pastoral Office-The Ordination of the Ministry of Word and Sacraments.Session 3: The Local Church-An Institutional Organization and a Living Organism.Session 4: The Pastor as the PriestSession 5: The Pastor as the Celebrant; Administration of Holy Baptism and Holy CommunionSession 6: The Pastor as Preacher and Teacher;Session 7: Preaching According to the Church Calendar and Planning of the Pulpit.Session 8: The Pastor as a Person (2)--Pastor’s Capability: Gifts, Spirituality, Attitude and Mental Hygiene. Session 9: The Pastor as ProphetSession 10: The Pastor as CounselorSession 11: The Pastor as Leader and Change AgentSession 12: Pastoral Ethics

title: Denominational Tradition and Polity
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course is aimed at deepening the students’ understanding of the historical background, the theological basis and the church practice of one of the denominational traditions of the supporting churches of Divinity School of Chung Chi College. The critical reflection of the denominational tradition and polity equips the students to identify patterns of transformation and change in a denominational tradition and guide them in devising strategies for the continuous reform of tradition and polity.

title: Homiletics
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course will cover: 1) the principles, construction and technique in preaching; and2) the content and message of a sermon in contemporary world. This course will include video-taping students’ preaching. Tutorials after preaching will be conducted for the improvement of technique and content.
outcome: To understand the principle of preaching on theological topics. To understand the integration of different types of preaching and the way of preparation. To learn and practice the techniques and styles in delivering a sermon.

title: Liturgics
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course aims at equipping students with the understanding of the history and theology of the sacred worship, which include the development of the sacred worship, the notion of liturgical time, of ecclesiastical year, of sacred space, of Monastic and Cathedral office, of the liturgy of the hours. It also helps student to gain a critical understanding on various liturgical terms, liturgical vessels, books and vestments. Contextualization of liturgy in Chinese/HK contexts will also be discussed.

title: Preaching
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Through lectures, reading and self-studies, students learn how to compose and deliver sermon. Special emphasis will be given to Biblical exposition, progression of thoughts, flow of feelings, use of illustrations, relevancy, and deliver styles. Critiques, suggestions, or comments by the instructor and interaction in a small group will be facilitated. Each student is expected to deliver a full-length sermon in front of other students two to three times a semester and hand in the relevant scripts at the same time. Students need to hand in the revised scripts in two weeks’ time.
outcome: Learn how to compose and deliver sermons of 30 minutes and learn how to make comments and give suggestions to sermons preached by others.

title: Death and Dying
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course explores the meaning of death and its related issues from different perspectives, namely, religious, pastoral, philosophical and sociological in order that students can develop sensitivity and skill in meeting and serving the dying as well as the bereaved.

title: Foundation of Religious Education
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at providing opportunities for students:1. To look at the foundational theories of Religious Education;2. To deepen their knowledge and understanding of such theories from the perspective of the Christian religion;3. To apply such theories in assessing exercises of assessing courses/programs of Christian Education currently used in denominations and local churches;4. To apply such theories by developing a model of Christian Education with a new approach entitled “Praxis in Dimensions”.

title: Approaches to Mission Studies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course introduces students to the broad subject of mission studies and the understanding of issues related to the mission of the church. In particular it will lead to a deeper understanding about the biblical basis of the mission of the church, about the historical development of Christian mission, about contemporary challenges that the mission of the churches faces, about patterns of mission today, about contextualization, more particularly about mission in the context of Hong Kong and China.

title: Christian Ethics
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course examines the context, nature, method and principles of Christian ethics. Emphasis is given to contemporary challenges to and of Christian ethics.
outcome: 1. To understand the diversities of Christian ethics and its challenges. 2. To acquire students with knowledge to critically reflect the contemporary issues. 3. To make appropriate critical connections between the study of Christian ethics, practical theology and biblical studies. 4. To appreciate the impact that one’s values and decisions make on the lives of oneself and others.
syllabus: 1.Critiques of morality2.Religion and morality3.Theories of Ethics4.Foundations (1): Jesus Christ and Christian ethics5.Foundations (2): The Bible and Christian ethics6.Foundations (3): Natural law and Christian ethics7.Foundations (4): Religious life and practice8.Foundations (5): History of Christian Ethics9.Moral agent (1) : The Church10.Moral agent (2) : Spirituality and Morality11.Christian ethics in contexts (1): Different models of Christian ethics12.Christian ethics in contexts (2): Contemporary challenges13.Christian ethics in contexts (3): Chinese religious context

title: Preaching Bible in Contexts
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course encourages and equips contextual interpretation and contextual proclamation of the Bible. "Contexts" are existential, life-oriented and multifaceted, e.g. political, economic, cultural, geographical, religious, personal growth, etc. "Context" could also be determined by liturgical demands such as Sunday sermon, baptism, Eucharist, festival, funeral, wedding ceremony and so forth. Students are expected to bridge the ancient biblical context(s) with the contemporary life context(s).

title: Homiletics and Selected Reading of the Bible
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course encourages dialogue between pastors and biblical scholar(s) concerning theory and praxis. Both parties are engaged to build up a constructive relationship between critical exegesis and ecclesiastical preaching. Sermon topic related to specific area of biblical studies (such as Wisdom Literature, Pauline Letters, the Apocalypse of John, etc.) will be selected. Instead of motivational speaking, students are expected to prepare and deliver sermons in light of scholarly consensus, updated biblical studies and accountable exposition of the Bible.

title: Teaching Bible in Church and School
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course investigates the history, current situation and new trends of educational ministry within the Church and schools with church background (including local churches, denominations, kindergartens, primary schools and secondary schools). Implementation experiences of "Sunday" school, Bible study group and religious studies subjects at school are consolidated and evaluated. Strategies for better implementation of Bible teaching are formulated. Students are expected to manage and plan the Bible ministries in their church or school setting effectively.

title: The Bible and Worship
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course concerns itself with the liturgical study of selected psalms, the investigation of the Sitz im Leben of the church in worship; much attention will be given to the didactic materials bearing on corporate worship in the Bible and their application for today’s church.

title: Theology of Worship
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Worship is styled as theologia prima, and doctrine as theologia secunda；not a few hymnic and confessional materials are found in the New Testament. The course will discuss various theologies of worship, the pastoral therapeutic efficacy of the sacraments, the functions of signs and symbols bearing on worship.

title: Congregational Hymns and Pastoral Care
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The course concerns itself with the criteria and evaluation of congregational hymns and their liturgical function in corporate worship; the selection of congregational hymns for the church calendar and theme of worship; their dual function of expression and impression for pastoral care.

title: Planning and Leading Worship Service
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course explores the practical ways of planning and leading public worship service of our time applying the reflections of biblical and historical perspectives of worship. Special attention will be given to diverse expressions of worship elements, creative ways of leading corporate worship, and evaluation of current worship practices. Students collaborate to plan and lead worship service.

title: Church Organist Training
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: The class discusses the skills and techniques of hymn playing and anthem accompanying on the organ. Students will learn how to combine organ repertoire into church liturgies, and also explore different styles of service playing from the Baroque period to the modern time. Students can take this course for up to 3 terms (total of 3 credits). Pianists are welcomed to register for the course but an audition will be required.

title: Preaching According to the Lectionary
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Preaching according to the lectionary is a time-honored tradition of the church. The four lessons of Old Testament, Psalm, Epistle and the Gospel for the Sunday are carefully arranged to be read and preached according to the liturgical year. The course concerns itself with the liturgical, spiritual import as well as the pastoral application of the lectionary for today’s church alongside the understanding of the basics and recent discussions of homiletics.

title: Life Education in Hong Kong
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Christian Studies
description: The course is to explore ideas, practices and pedagogies of life education in Hong Kong, and its relation to new issues emerging from value education, such as national identity and service learning. Apart from lectures, this course will arrange workshops, local and/or overseas field trips.

title: Contemporary Issues in Ethics, Society and Religion
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course attempts to explore the complexity of contemporary issues raised by ethics and society through a religious perspective.

title: Religious Education and Personal Growth
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course will attempt to study some of the modern developmental theories such as Piaget’s cognitive developmental theory, Erikson’s socio-psychological theory, Kohlberg’s moral developmental theory and Fowlers’ faith developmental theory. Special attention will be given to the evaluation of their signifi cance to education in a religious context.

title: Culture, Religion and Ethics
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course attempts to articulate the creative inquiry into and conceptual interrelationship among culture, religion and ethics. Particular attention is given to the relevance of theological reflection for cultural analysis in public life, the advance of technology, the movement of economic order, the ambiguity of sexual issue and the pressing demands for dialogue between the world’s religions.

title: Religion and Ecological Crisis
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at introducing the students to the issues related to religion andenvironmental ethics. The course will cover the following aspects: the basic approaches in environmental ethics; how religions are related to the environmental problems; the worldview and ethics of the major religious traditions; and how contemporary religions respond to the environmental question.

title: THEORIES OF RELIGIOUS EDUCATION
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course examines various theories of religious education. It begins with an historical overview of different approaches to religious education. It then examines some influential theories of religious education, particularly James Fowler's comprehensive theory of faith development, Paulo Freire's praxis approach to education, and Thomas Groome's theory of Christian religious education. Students will explore contributions, as well as limitations, of these theories to religious education classroom of contemporary Hong Kong.

title: Christian Education in the Postmodern World
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course explores the dynamics of living in a postmodern world and its impact on Christian education. It will first describe the emergence and meaning of postmodernity. It will then explore its impact on religion in general and Christian education in particular. Issues like religious convictions, moral decisions, and character and spiritual formation will be of particular interest. Lastly, students are expected to rediscover the meanings of Christian education in the postmodern world.

title: Teaching/Learning Theories in Christian Education
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course explores theories of teaching and learning in an effort to enhance teaching effectiveness in the field of Christian Education. Attention will be given to the examination of historical and contemporary models of teaching/learning and, the development of personal pedagogies for Christian Education in schools and churches.

title: Christian Education and Character Formation
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course is designed to equip educators with vision and accompanying skills for aligning Christian education to character formation. Students will be guided in developing a general understanding of how character is formed in childhood and throughout the lifespan. Different psychological and philosophical theories of moral/character development, including Maslow, Erikson, Kohlberg, Gilligan, and McIntyre will be examined. Also, students will be assisted in developing practical strategies and methodologies for supporting character development in the context of Christian Education.

title: Methods and Paradigms of Christian Studies
requirements: For students in MA in Christian Studies and MA in Religious Studies programmes.
description: This course aims at providing students with a solid methodological and theoretical understanding of the multidisciplinary study of Christianity. It mainly introduces the students to the principal tasks (e.g., historical, constructive, practical) and methods, together with their theoretical presuppositions, of Christian studies. It also acquaints students with major theological paradigms (e.g., traditional, liberal, liberationist, feminist, etc.) and their different visions of the theological disciplines (e.g., biblical studies, history of Christianity, systematic theology, pastoral studies, etc.). Issues such as the relation of Christian studies to other academic fields, the alleged conflict between its scientific and ecclesial orientations, and the interconnection of its diverse disciplines, will be discussed.
outcome: 1. To obtain a broadened and deepened understanding of the major traditions of Christianity in the world in historical and comparative perspectives 2. To be able to understand major theological paradigms in Christianity with their internal complexity, and be able to extend such understanding to issues in church and society 3. To have some knowledge of the tasks and methods of the major disciplines in Christian studies and be able to apply such knowledge in research
syllabus: 1.Introduction. Christianity as Multi- Paradigmatic.2.Historical-Theological Paradigms (1): Early Jewish-Christian Apocalyptic; Patristic Hellenistic Orthodox3.Historical-Theological Paradigms (2): Mediaeval Latin Roman Catholic; Reformation Protestant.4.Theological Research and Paper Writing5.The Tasks and Methods of Biblical Studies6.The Tasks and Methods of History of Christianity7.Historical-Theological Paradigms (3): Modernity; Liberal Theology; Neo-Orthodox Theology.8.Historical-Theological Paradigms (4): Evangelicalism; Pentecostalism9.The Tasks and Methods of Systematic Theology10.Historical-Theological Paradigms (5): Liberation Theology; Feminist Theology.11.The Tasks and Methods of Practical Theology12.Global Christianity in the 21st century13.Interdisciplinary approaches to Christian Studies

title: New Testament in Contexts
requirements:
Exclusion=Not for students who have taken THEO5312 Introduction to the New Testament
For students in MA Religious Studies or MA Christian Studies
description: This course will select some texts of the New Testament with contemporary methods for in-depth study. Texts include selected themes of the Pauline Epistles, Synoptic Gospels and Johannine Literature, e.g., Pauline Epistle Form, Doctrinal and Ethical Teachings; Eucharist, Baptism, Miracles and Teachings of the Synoptics; as well as Revelation structure, “I am saying”, Farewell Discourse of the Gospel of John.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: Expected Knowledge Outcomes 1. Know how to find reliable and trustworthy resources for their own reconstruction of socio-historical contexts of the New Testament; 2. Compare and contrast New Testament studies in public domain with uncritical voices by means of established paradigms and academic consensus; Expected Skills Outcome 3. Analyze context(s) behind primary texts and evaluate their relevance in biblical exegeses; (* This also serve as a preparation of key research skills for graduate work in advanced biblical studies) Expected Attitude Outcome 4. Deepen their critical and yet sympathetic understanding of earliest Christian traditions in our contemporary contexts and appraise their contributions in shaping different cultures.
syllabus: • Matrix and Methods (NT as sacred text and historical source, social historical contexts of Judaismand Greco-Roman culture in the first century, textual criticism, source criticism, form criticism,redaction criticism, narrative criticism, sociological approach, ideology criticism, history ofeffects)• The Four Gospels (Mark, Matthew, Luke, John; literary design and social historical contexts,Christology and discipleship)• Paul’s Letters (Philemon, First Thessalonians, First Corinthians, Romans, Galatians; contexts andcontents; crises and messages)• Other Writings (Pastoral Epistles, Peter’s Letters, Hebrews, Revelation; hostile contexts, churchformation in the world, hope beyond now)

title: Contextual Interpretation of the Bible
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course introduces some methodologies to read the Bible texts, where the perspectives of readers take primary focus. Defined by their specific contexts such as social, political, historical, philosophical and theological ones, it instructs how one can interpret the Bible meaningfully for their communities of faith. Some of these include postcolonial and post-imperialist interpretations, ethnic interpretations, and interpretations for the disabled, etc. Emphases are given to how these methodologies come about and has developed in the academic disciplines, the components of these methodologies and how they may be applied to the reading of the Bible.
outcome: 1. Describe and explain the historical, political, social, cultural and economic contexts of particular communities.  2. Review and analyse the scholarship of the biblical text/s and theology, and explain how traditional interpretations of the Bible in Christian history marginalize and oppress these communities. 3. Delineate the history of oppression of these communities by Christian theology and interpretations. 4. Review and evaluate how recent scholarship in Contextual Interpretations of the Bible contributes to specific communities. Point out the specific contributions as well as criticize the limitations. Make judgments on the relevance and significance of such interpretations, taking seriously as well the contexts of the biblical books. 5. Construct and propose a re-interpretation of a bible passage/book for a specific marginalized community, taking into their contexts as primary focus and finding points of relevance in the biblical passage/book.

title: Methods and Biblical Interpretation
requirements: For students in MA in Christian Studies, Master of Divinity
description: Biblical interpretation does not happen in a vacuum. Every interpretive act involves the text, the reader, and its signifying context, including that of the writer(s) and that of the reader, defined by the complex web of social, cultural, political, and even psychological forces. This course covers some major methods used in the critical study of the Bible (with a focus on the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament) from the late nineteenth century to the early twenty-first century, including the historical-critical methods, literary criticism, and reader-centered approaches. It examines the tasks, presuppositions, and reading strategies of various exegetical methods, and evaluates each’s weaknesses and strengths.

title: The Hebrew Bible in Contexts
requirements:
Exclusion=Not for students who have taken THEO5311 Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
For students in MA Christian Studies
description: "This course aims at introducing students to the approaches to reading the Hebrew Bible (The Christian Old Testament) in its literary, socio-political and religio-cultural contexts. The literary setting and historical background will be surveyed and explored in order to enhance students’ understanding of the text and the dynamics of the reading process."
outcome: Knowledge Outcomes (1) Describe a. what the study of Hebrew Bible constitutes. b. with the help of resources, the general background and contexts of the biblical books. (2) Explain a. the necessity of understanding contexts of when studying the Hebrew Bible. b. the literary, socio-political and religio-cultural contexts of a specified period in biblical history. c. the necessity and limitations in biblical scholarship for reconstructing contexts. (3) Distinguish a. what is “historical Israel” and “biblical Israel”. b. the different contexts for interpreting scriptures. (4) Recite the main historical epochs of biblical Israel. (5) Examine and analyse the contexts of a given text using quality resources. (6) Sketch an interpretation of a given text integrating a current context to a passage in the Hebrew Bible. (7) Comment and evaluate on those information that were presented differently in church. Determine the consequences of the information.  (8) Reflect and discuss on the implications of academic study and its impact on faith-based communities.  (9) Construct interpretations that take the contexts of the biblical text/s seriously and also relevant to one’s context.  Attitude Outcomes: (1) Appreciate by listing the contributions of the diverse interpretations of scriptures throughout history and their historical and contextual developments. (2) Respect for the historical development of Old Testament scholarship in its entirety by pointing out their relevance to current contexts – within the communities of faith and also within the academia. (3) Develop keen insights to read texts meaningfully and responsibly by reading up and constructing different contextual interpretations of biblical texts – for the sake of peace and justice, understanding and acceptance to all humanity and living creatures of God’s creation.

title: Contextual Theologies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course tries to critically examine several features of all theological endeavours: particularity, contextuality and historicity. It also articulates how theologies are spatially and temporally shaped. Accordingly, the relationship between theology and context will not be conceived as a kind of linear application of some ready-made theologies to the contemporary contexts, but a kind of interpretive effort which tries to correlate the Christian traditions with the contemporary cultural, socio-political and economical context. It will also discuss the practical dimension of the ‘doing’ of theologies. It is according to all this that some examples of contextual theology will be introduced.
outcome: Knowledge: Students acquire the following and/or critically reflect on them-- 1. The contextuality and situatedness of theological knowledge; 2. The history of contextual theology; 3. Deep understanding of at least four types of contextual theology; 4. Methods and Methodologies of doing practical theology; 5. Read at least one classic text in the field of contextual theology. Attitude: students be able to fully appreciate that  1. The value of a living faith lies in its openness and contextual relevance; 2. Theologically sound ideas are often praxis-oriented. Skill: students be able to theologically analyze and interpret social/cultural/political issues going on in their own context.

title: Modern Christian Thinkers
requirements: For students in MA Christian Studies and Master of Divinity
description: The course introduces the work and thought of some of the important theologians of the 20th century. Western thought since the period of the Enlightenment has understood human beings as autonomous from God. Modern science and human rationality left no place for God. The course attempts to understand how Christian faith and theology reacts to this challenge of modernity by presenting and studying different theological responses to it. The course puts emphasis on the reading of primary sources of various theologians.

title: Asian Theologies
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Asia is a large continent with the largest population in the world and a diverse cultural heritage. Though Christianity was born in West Asia, its expansion to South and East Asia happened rather recently. In the last few decades, Asians have begun to utilize their own resources and context in theological endeavour. This course attempts to investigate some of the theologies emerging in Asia.

title: Christianity in Chinese Religious Context
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course aims at studying Chinese Christianity in the Chinese religious context. Special emphasis will be given to the question as to how Christianity has been viewed in and shaped by the Chinese religious context. Comparison between some of the Chinese Christian phenomena and their counterparts in the traditional Chinese religions will be made, e.g., the Taiping Christianity vis-à-vis the Buddhist or Taoist Messianic movements. Issues on Christianity faces in the Chinese religious context will also be discussed, e.g., syncretism and dual religious citizenship.

title: Christianity and Social Change
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: In the absence of any social theory that is uniquely “Christian”, this course will seek to study the positions of the Christian churches on various political and social issues as they seek to define for themselves their role in a rapidly changing world. Asian models and the more traditional Western approaches to similar issues will be compared in order to highlight the strength and weaknesses of each in the common attempt to balance the Christian ideal and social realities.

title: Chinese Christianities
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course examines various issues regarding the course of Christianity indigenization and contextualization in China, such as the development of Nestorian Christianity in Tang Dynasty, Jesuits mission and the Rites Controversy, the issue of Chinese Bible translation and Christian literature, Christianity and social reform and reconstruction in China, independent churches and evangelists in China, and the issue of Christianity and races. By discussing the above issues, this course shall explore how the Chinese experience would contribute to the enrichment of church universal.
outcome: Students are expected to, by the end of the course, 1. Show their concrete knowledge of certain terms and concepts, such as indigenization, contextualisation, localisation, inculturation and interculturation. 2. Be able to critically reflect on issues regarding Christianity indigenization in China from historical perspectives. 3. Demonstrate their abilities to reflect on and evaluate, from theological perspectives, the efforts towards Christianity indigenization by Chinese Christians.

title: Christianity and Chinese Culture
requirements: For students in MA Religious Studies or Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: Starting from the traditional understanding of indigenization whereby culture are often looked upon as static entities, Christianity and Chinese culture will also be compared as they moved through the recent history of China as two living forces competing to shape the China that was to be. This is an open-ended course which will continuously be informed by recent trends and developments.

title: Christianity in Twentieth Century China
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course examines the development of Christian thoughts and institutions in China from the early twentieth century to the present.

title: History of Christian Thought
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course consists of a critical survey of the history of the development of Christian (mainly theological) thought. It will concentrate on analysis of several decisive phrases of development and will attempt to show the interaction between Christian thought and its historical circumstances.
outcome: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have a solid overview of the development of Christian thought, including the diversity of views, major historical developments, and significant issues involved, and their interrelations; (b) to be able to understand and appreciate some important theologians, including their life and thought; (c) to be able to critically articulate the relevance of Christian thoughts in personal life, churches, and society.
syllabus: Introduction1. The definition of the title and the aims and structure of this courseThe Early Church and the Formation of Catholicism2. The emergence of Christianity from the second temple Judaism3. The way the scriptures were interpreted and the formation of the early tradition4. The significance and development of early creeds, dogma and doctrinesThe Medieval Period and Eastern Thought5. A brief outline of the development of the Eastern Christian thought6. Augustine’s thought and his influence: a person one cannot avoid7. Is the medieval period really dark? Plus a survey of scholasticism and mysticismThe Reformation and its Consequence8. Is the Reformation really a break? The tension of Christian thought at the time9. The afterlife of the Reformation: from enchantment to disenchantment?10. At the dawn of the Enlightenment: Orthodoxy, Rationalism, Pietism, and so onThe Enlightenment and Beyond11. The challenges of modernity to Christianity and the rise of new thought waves12. The rapid change of theological drama of the “short” twentieth century13. The so-called post-modern shift and the search for Christian identity14. Roundup and conclusion

title: Public Theology
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course helps students perceive doing theology as taking place within the ethical debates of society as a whole. It introduces different ways of how theology has entered or can entered, both historically and methodologically, into debate on shared ground with social sciences, politics and economics, etc. Different theological perspectives, such as those put forward by Reinhold Niebuhr, Max Stackhouse, and Duncan Forrester on the one hand, and Howard Yoder, Stanley Hauerwas, John Milbank and others, on the other hand, will be discussed. Students will also be shown how these perspectives can be applied to the discussion of local public issues.
outcome: 1. To review critically different theological opinions on public theologies. 2. To be engaged into a fruitful dialogue between theology and other disciplines, such as, politics and economics on public life. 3. To correlate the knowledge developed in the course to the Christian practice in Hong Kong, and to evaluate it critically . 4. To use public reasoning to communicate the findings to a range of audiences.
syllabus: 1.Introduction: Methodological (1): What Public Theology is: theology and stewardship, authority of pubic theology 。2.Methodological (2) Church, Faith and Public Theology。3.Methodological (3) What Public Theology is not:different from political theology, civil religion, and others 。4.Descriptive (1) Calvinism, Abraham Kuyper, and Worldview 。5.Descriptive (2) : Abraham Kuyper on Common Grace。6.Descriptive (3) Abraham Kuyper and Herman Dooyeweerd: Creation Order and Sphere Sovereignty 。7.Descriptive (4) Reinhold Niebuhr: Christian Realism。8.Constructive (1) Christian theology and human rights:Trinity, Image of God, and Human Dignity 。9.Constructive (2) Christian theology and human rights: Love, Justice, and Human Rights。10.Constructive (3) Christian theology and human rights: Calvinism and human rights。11.Public Theology in the Chinese Context : Reformed Public Theology in Chinese Churches and Sino-Christian Public Theology 。12. Conclusion, Presentation & Consultation。

title: Theology and Work
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: Work can be a creative expression of the way one professes commitment, service and personal gift to a community. This course is to provide a Christian critique of the contemporary practice of work and retrieve the dignity of work. Concepts related to work like vocation, leisure, play and Sabbath would be discussed.

title: Media, Popular Culture and Christianity
requirements: For students in MA in Christian Studies, Master of Divinity and MA in Religious Studies programmes
description: This course is a critical exploration of the intricate relationships between popular media culture and Christianity. While popular culture and the media have long become a daily reality for many in the world, these have seldom been taken seriously by theologians and scholars of religion. Also, the relationship between popular media and religion (including Christianity) is often overlooked in academic studies until relatively recent time. We shall re-examine various manifestations of popular culture from Christian theological perspectives, and also probes into the subtle interrelatedness between media culture and Christianity as an organised religion. As its wider academic context, this course engages with the interdisciplinary field of media, religion, and culture (MRC) which has been under vigorous development since the mid-1990s; as its immediate socio-cultural-religious context of discussions, it attends particularly to the Chinese language popular media and Chinese Christianity in Hong Kong.

description: Discussion in seminar setting on specific issues related to Theological Studies. Students are allowed to take these courses for more than once.

requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: This course is designed to equip students with concept and skill necessary for them to engage in pastoral work in contemporary context through worship, preaching, teaching, fellowship and service of the church.

requirements: For students in Master of Divinity

title: Christian Counselling
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course will cover the following areas: 1) the similarities and differences between Christian Counselling and General Counselling; 2) the similarities and differences between Pastoral Counselling and Pastoral Care; 3) different approaches to Christian Counselling; and 4) skills, knowledge and practical competence in Christian Counselling.
outcome: Knowledge: Students acquire the following and/or critically reflect on them-- 1. The history and traditions of Christian counseling 2. The similarities and differences between Christian counseling and General Counseling; 3. The similarities and differences between Christian counseling and pastoral care; 4. Different approaches to Christian counseling; 5. Counseling ministries in some specific settings, such as bereavement, depression, crisis situations, etc. 6. Read at least one classic text in the field of Christian counseling. Attitude: students be able to fully appreciate 1. The Christianness of Christian counseling; 2. The need to integrate Christian counseling with theological understanding; 3. The need to critically draw insights from social scientific understandings of human being and human society. Skill: students be able to  1. Do basic counselling guidance work in Christian settings under professional supervision.

title: Counselling and Youth Ministry
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course aims at helping students to: 1) acquire a critical and historical understanding on the theorization of youth and adolescent; 2) acquire a general knowledge on various models of youth counselling in Christian settings; 3) enhance their competence in facilitating youth to growth and helping youth in troubles; and 4) reflect on the theological and practical issues behind youth counselling in Christian context.

title: Counselling and Family Ministry
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course aims at helping students to: 1) acquire a general knowledge on various models of systemic family therapy and their application to Christian ministries; 2) enhance their competence in delivering counselling services to couples and families in troubles; 3) reflect on the theological and practical issues behind family counselling in Christian context.

title: Theology and Counseling Theories
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
description: This course serves two basic functions: first, to equip students with a basic understanding on the contemporary general counseling theories: second, to enhance students’ competence to read these theories theologically. The methodology adopted will be a kind of mutually critical correlation. Substantively, the course will introduce six to seven contemporary counseling theories, which will be followed by theological critiques on them.

title: Theology and Hong Kong Society
requirements: Pre-requisite = THEO5906 Methods and Paradigms of Christian Studies or THEO5336 Systematic Theology II
description: This course equips students with knowledge and skills in theologizing with an interdisciplinary horizon across a variety of aspects of everyday practical life in Hong Kong. It helps students to see how different sub-disciplines of theology can be critically integrated into a coordinated whole and in this way be relevant to the practical life in one's own context. Social and theological analysis are given equal emphasis, and how these two could be mutually and critically correlated will be demonstrated. Experts or/and experienced practitioners in different fields of practice will be invited to share with students their analyses of the respective public/current issues, while theological responses (philosophical, exegetical, historical, and practical) will be given by teachers from different sub-disciplines in theology. Around half of the lectures will be structured in the form of an interdisciplinary dialogue.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should be able to achieve the below:   Knowledge Aspect 1. Acquire a general but critical framework to integrate various sub-disciplines of theology for a practical analysis and evaluation of the Hong Kong society. 2. Demonstrate a contextual understanding of a variety of models of publicization of theology.  Skill Aspect 1. Acquire the ability to apply an interdisciplinary approach to a theological analysis and evaluation of the Hong Kong society in some selected aspects (please refer to Course Syllabus). 2.Begin to be able to formulate one's own initial interdisciplinary framework to do contextual theological analyses of one's own place.   Values and Attitudes Aspect 1.Appreciate the importance of an interdisciplinary horizon to any theological understanding of one's own society.  2.Critically aware of the role of theology in public sphere of one's own place. 3.Appreciate the value of defragmentation of theological study.
syllabus: This course will be composed of two core sections.  Core Section 1: Three Major Lenses or Models for understanding the possible ways for theology to engage the public sphere will be introduced briefly. The principal aim of this section is to equip the students with basic frameworks to understand and engage in the dialogical platform that constitutes the second core section.  1. Introduction:  a. David Tracy's "theology as public discourse for public realm" as the theological orientation of Christian faith and praxis. b. Three kinds of publicness that mark theological discourse. c. David Tracy’s notion of “the public at large” and its relationship with practical theology. d. The tradition of the public relevance of theology. e. A practical-prophetic ecclesiology.  2. Public Theology as a Dialogical Lens a. What is public theology? b. Models of public theology as advanced by Eneida Jacobsen. c. Local examples.  3. Practical Theology as a Dialogical Lens a. Practical theology as a transformative discourse b. The correlational relationship between different theological sub-movements (descriptive, historical, systematic, and strategic practical) and praxis. c. Types of practical-theological reflection as advanced by Elaine Graham, Heather Walton, and Frances Ward. d. Local examples.  4. Political Theology and Liberation Theology as Dialogical Lenses a. History and types of political theology and liberation theology. b. Political theology and liberation theology as critical-prophetic witness of the church. c. Emancipation and liberation as core themes for theologizing.  d. Local examples.  Core Section 2: Interdisciplinary Dialogical Platform to experiment on the ways for theology to engage concrete public issues. Around five public/current issues from the below area-list will be selected each year for the dialogue. Experts or/and experienced practitioners in different fields of practice will be invited to the platform to share with students their analyses of the respective public/current issues, while theological responses (philosophical, exegetical, historical, and practical) will be given by teachers from different sub-disciplines in theology. Students are expected to engage in the dialogue with the theories and concepts they learnt from core section 1, and with their own experience as a citizen. They will also be required to continue the discussion on the eLearning platform (Blackboard) which constitutes one of their homework assignments.  1. Land Use in Hong Kong; and, Land in the Hebrew Bible: The dialogue will focus on issues related to sustainability, conservation, development, environmental justice, and theologies of territory in the Hebrew Bible.  2. Poverty and Justice in Hong Kong; and, Church and the Struggle for Social Justice: The dialogue will focus on (a) the different ways (social scientific and theological) of describing, categorizing, explaining, and interpreting the phenomenon of poverty in Hong Kong; (b) how can the church build a movement of Christians committed to tackling poverty in Hong Kong?  3. Sex, Marriage and Family in Hong Kong; and, En-Gendering Theology: LGBT issues in Hong Kong will be critically discussed. Different ways of Christian responses will be examined.  4. Mainland-Hong Kong Relations; and Church-State Relations: The changing Mainland-HK relations amid integration and confrontation will be discussed. Beijing’s policy toward HK and the local reactions in the midst of socio-economic integration in the recent decade will be the focus. This changing phenomenon will be critically engaged with various theological perspectives of church-state relations.  5. Rule of Law in Hong Kong; and Rule of Law and Christian Traditions: “Is Hong Kong’s rule of law under threat?” “How is the rule of law to be understood, and understood in the local context?” “How shall we understand the biblical foundations for the rule of law in the Western world?” “How shall Christian communities respond to the concerned local debates?” These questions will form the focal concern of the dialogue.  6. Selected issues in Social Policy; and Christian Vision of a Good Society: one concrete issue regarding local social policy on housing, labor, social welfare, medical and health care, education, or social security, etc. will be selected for the dialogue. How Christian visions of a good society can engage in the debate will be examined.  7. Other Important Public Affairs that take place during the Teaching Period

title: Pastoral Studies: Seminar I
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: A study in depth of one or more topics and issues arising in pastoral studies and Christian nurture, such as counselling in special occasions, liturgies, local church and community, lay training, church growth, Christian stewardship, etc. Students are allowed to take these courses for more than once, and gain the units each time they pass the course.
outcome: 1. To critically review, consolidate, and extend knowledge with special reference to one or more selected topics or issues on pastoral studies.  2. To analyze, evaluate, and/or synthesize ideas, concepts, and perspectives to address critically and constructively certain issues on pastoral studies.  3. To deepen the understanding of the diversity and complexity of theological positions and perspectives and to make informed judgment in pastoral studies.
syllabus: Please refer to the course outlines provided by the course teacher.
required_readings: Further readings will be provided alongside lecture contents. Please consult the course teacher(s) for the most up-to-date reading list.
recommended_readings: Further readings will be provided alongside lecture contents. Please consult the course teacher(s) for the most up-to-date reading list.

title: Field Education III
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: (a) 2 units per term representing a minimum of eight hours supervised field work per week; or (b) 4 units for full-time supervised field work for at least eight weeks during the summer vacation.
outcome: 1. Aim: The aim of Supervised Field Education is to acquaint students with areas of ministry, assist them in the pursuit of theory-practice integration, help them improve knowledge and skills in ministry and examine themselves, their roles, their relationship with the Christian community and their call in ministry within the context of experiencing ministry. 2. Outcomes: Students be able to  2.1 gain insights into how theory be integrated with practice; 2.2 learn to read living experience pastorally and theologically; 2.3 learn to do theological reflection in ministerial context; 2.4 understand how one’s self has shaped his/her ministry; 2.5 examine his/her own vocational calling, acquire basic ministerial skills; 2.6 develop personal and inter-personal skills appropriate to the particular setting where the field work takes place.
syllabus: Pastoral ministries of local /oversea church,  Ministries of Christian organizations, Clinical Pastoral Education.
required_readings: 1.Field work Handbook of DSCCC2.Sexual Harassment Prevention training (co-organized by DSCCC and Hong Kong Christian Council)3.Field work orientation
recommended_readings: Readings from all Pastoral Studies courses.

title: Clinical Pastoral Education
requirements: For students in Master of Divinity
description: Clinical Pastoral Education (CPE) is a mode of theological education that has a history of several decades. It facilitates pastoral growth through action-reflection mode of learning in clinical settings. This course requires students to complete one unit of CPE programme at a training center recognized by the Divinity School.
